name: Anonymous
com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

I myself consider ebikes as kind of cheating. One reason why I use a bicycle for commute is that I also get a bit of incidental exercise while I am at it. Having an assisting bicycle would take that out of the equation too. (I am overweight. I am working on it though.) But, for people who primarly just want a mean of transportation, that should be fine. At least you wouldn't suffer from the gasoline price hikes. I also wonder how awfull the ebikes are to drive with after you run out of battery. Afaik the range is only about 50km with them anyways. When I go out on my cycling camping trips, I go about 40-80km in a day, depending on the nature of the trip and my other plans. There aren't mountains in my area so I don't need assistance when going up the hill. I have been doing this all on an older city-bike that my grandma gave me. It is in top notch condition though.

And to answer the questions;
1: In my opinion, very.
2: I wouldn't buy one.
3: The perks are that the (((tax man))) doesn't get a penny, unless like with combustion engine vehicles.

com:
I've bought both packs to try on at home and I've noticed that many people seem to strongly prefer one or the other. What's standing out to me is that they're both like 90% the same pack.

As far as I can tell, these are the differences.

The Aether has a rigid back panel (along with a higher weight rating), heat moldable shoulder and hip straps, compression straps across the "shove-it" pouch, and a large zip that goes across the entire pack, to access anything without having to go through the traditional drawstring opening on the top.

The Atmos has the non-rigid mesh (Antigravity) packpanel (I've had problems with items poking me in the back because of this), shoulder straps and hip belt, trekking pole attachments on the shoulder strap, and a large side zip on each side to access the interior of the pack, instead of the Aether's full zip. The Atmos also has a dual front zipper pouch that isn't mentioned on the product manual for some reason. The Atmos weights 139 grams less, which is nothing imo.

Aside from those few differences, they're literally the same pack.

Oddly enough the Aether has "more features", but a lower price. I'm not sure what that's about.

I find the torso length adjustments on the Atmos dig into my back occasionally. I'm really not liking that.

For those who have tried both packs, which one do you prefer?

com:
>On Nov 15, 2022, around 5:20 p.m., Idaho County Dispatch received a call from the International Emergency Response Coordination Center. They had received an SOS from a Garmin Inreach device belonging to Jonathan Conti, videographer/YouTuber, of Boise. The location given was just north of the Walton Lakes, which is south of the Powell Ranger Station, between the Elk Summit Rd (Forest Service Road 360) and Tom Beal Park Road (Forest Service Road 362).

>Idaho County Dispatch used the link provided by IERCC to message with Conti. Conti stated he needed rescued as he had snowshoed in, but had dropped down into a canyon that he couldn’t climb out of due to the snow being too thick. He had food, water and shelter and was safe for the night. He had parked his vehicle on Elk Summit Road about five miles from his location and was not familiar with the area, but told dispatch that he could make it to Walton Lake if that was a better rescue spot.

>On Nov. 16, 2022, Idaho County Sergeant Keith Olsen and Idaho County Deputy Stan Denham responded at first light. Idaho County Dispatch advised Conti to head to the Walton Lakes Trailhead, which was about half a mile from his location, and gave him coordinates to where he could be picked up by the deputies. Idaho County Deputies left the Powell Ranger Station by snowmobile on the Tom Beal Road. They cut numerous fallen trees out of the road to get to the Walton Lakes Trailhead.

name: Anonymous
com:
Hello Out

I want to go on a long and extended walk/hike/trek in Scotland where wild camping is legal so I can relax for an extended period of time without slipping into decadence like people do at holiday resorts and have nothing to do but walk and read. I plan to do this summer 2023 after my A levels and before university. By then I will have at least £1000 in savings and probably more (I now have about £900). Will this be feasible.

£1.70 for a weeks worth of rice
£0.60 for a weeks worth of carrots
£5 for two lamb chops
£3 for a roll of proper bread (normal supermarket bread in the uk is actually a bread substitute but if you’re willing to pay extra you can get actual bread quite easily).

I should note that I’m an autist so I won’t mind eating mostly rice with other food in smaller amounts to get necessary nutrients and would probably prefer it over variation as I like routine.

I imagine I could roast vegetables easily in a mess tin (German/polish/Russian variety) and make a decent if oddly shaped Yorkshire pudding in the removable dish that comes with the mess kit.

Shelter: bothies. Carry a zeltbhan in case I can’t find a bothy.

Entertainment: the natural world+books. I will buy books to read on the trip and then pass them on or something when I’m done with them.

Clothes:
I’ll bring 2 pairs of trousers and 3/4 cotton or linen shirts. I’ll also bring a jumper or two. Will be packed in a rucksack.

I also want to do this to prove to my friends that cost of living is low outside of rent and vices
but that is an afterthought that came to me whilst typing this post. My main motivation is a sense of wanderlust and desire for solitude to think and to read.

Misc:
Needles+thread
Lighter
Swiss army knife
Water bottle
Might bring an axe
Torch

Anything I’ve missed? Is this feasible?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505180
Cooking regular rice may take too long/use up too much fuel, if that's not an issue maybe look into using brown rice instead and adding in some red split lentils which should cook fully with the rice. If not there's always couscous or other grains which may cook faster than just plain rice. (Could go with minute rice for example)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505175
That’s about 10 meals worth of rice, if you’re eating 2 servings (1 cup/3.25oz total, 370 calories). I don’t think anyone is eating just plane rice. Adding high calorie protein, such as chorizo, makes an entire meal.


1cup instant rice
3oz chorizo
1tbsp tomato powder
1 bouillon cube
1/2tsp Italian seasoning

Cut the chorizo into small pieces at home. Keep the seasoning, sausage, and rice separated. Add the seasoning to 8oz of water and bring to a boil. Stir in the sausage and let it boil for maybe 15 or 30 seconds. Stir in the rice, turn off your stove, cover, and let sit for 5 minutes.

It’s about 6.5oz(185g if you don’t believe in freedom) and 640 calories, if you use 3oz of chorizo. It contains 7.5g of fat and about 25g of protein, and 75g of carbs.

Other than being delicious, it’s great because it’s simple, can be found in a grocery store, cooks very easily, and uses very little water. It’s not really suitable for resupplying on the trail though; I’ve never seen tomato powder in anything other than very large containers.

Also to the OP struggling with this, I also am a spastic who does everything in cowboy boots. Entirely dependent on the sole and your sock choice, the rest is just a boot. A raised solid heel does not have great traction, consider hobnails or crampons appropriate for the terrain. The "modern" style with a Vibram boot sole or something similar is just a boot with a stylish top. I have cowboy boots that are CSA approved with steel toes and anti-slip soles, even. Not hard to style on your fellow tradie with such wear, and I wore those fuckers every single day of my life for everything I did for years, until I destroyed the bottoms in a motorcycle crash. I then cut the tops off, added grommets to them, and made them half-chaps so I could top any boot with the westerns. I like my fruity boots.

the debate over what killed Chris McCandless, and the related question of whether he is worthy of admiration, has been smoldering and occasionally flaring for more than two decades now. Shortly after the first edition of Into the Wild was published in January 1996, University of Alaska chemists Edward Treadwell and Thomas Clausen shot down my theory that the cause of McCandless’s death was a toxic alkaloid contained in the seeds of the Eskimo potato plant, Hedysarum alpinum, also known as wild potato. When Treadwell and Clausen completed chemical analyses of the Eskimo potato seeds I’d sent them, they found no trace of any poisonous compounds. “I tore that plant apart,” Dr. Clausen explained to Men’s Journal in 2007. “There were no toxins. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503889
Everyone has mentioned everything so far, but I'll add a shitload of cheap bungee cords for strapping things down and a set of spare scupper plugs (the rubber grommets that you pull out for drainage). They dry out over time and can get loose, especially if you get the kind of kayak cart that sticks up through the plug holes. There's nothing worse than having one pop out and float off when you're in the middle of nowhere. You won't sink, but you'll get a wet ass and feel miserable for the rest of the trip. They're only about $15 a dozen and you can just stash them inside the boat
>>2507498
Nah man. I've been floating down the same stretch of river for years and it never gets old. Everything changes with seasons and weather and the time of day or night. Also going to new bodies of water isn't a chore, like sometimes you visit a place for other reasons or pull off the road somewhere and think "fuck, I need to bring my kayak here" and you get all excited and start planning things for the weekend. Also: friends/mates/girls have a blast. I have two kayaks and just take people out and have a blast
>>2507621
Hell yeah man. I've been wanting one for a while but the river I live next to is an average of ~3 feet deep the whole way, like alpine trout fishing territory where a propeller would get wrecked within minutes because I'm too distracted by scenery to lift the thing before I bottom out

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507643
Depending on the kayak the OP should probably not go with scupper plugs. If the seat is raised off the bottom of the kayak then scupper plugs, in my opinion, aren't the way to go. Scupper holes provide drainage for water getting into the kayak. Most definitely won't be ideal for fishing in and launching in surf situations. There are scupper plugs that allow water to get out but not come in, though.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505036
There are kayaks advanced enough to allow you to stand in them. The Hobie Pro Angler series and some advanced model Old Town kayaks are tailor made for fishing while standing. I'd be cognizant of how the water is moving before I do so though.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2507498

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
A few other things that I've thought of that you may need.

>A VHF radio if fishing in areas where coast guard and rescue authorities can be reached by radio
>A dry suit or wet suit if fishing in cold water temperatures. You dress for immersion, not air temperature. May not want to be wearing cotton if in a cold water kayaking situation. Your body loses heat much faster when immersed in cold water than it does when dry. Cotton clothing retains water and accelerates the body cooling when wet. You want to go with synthetic fabrics or wool are generally better choices.
>A net is most definitely a must
>A stringer for keeping any fish you want to keep. I just purchased a large stainless steel fish stringer loop but you can use any cheapo stringer and just tie it somewhere on your kayak.

name: Anonymous
sub: Beginner Gear General - Poor Fag Edition
com:
I wanted to make a thread for General new gear and where to get it. Also for Larpers and Woodsman alike to avoid the pit falls I fell into when choosing gear for the first time over 2 years ago. i'll try to aim for a good gear loadout under 200$. Also any criticisms or better options should be talked about here.

Ill first go by stating the things no anon should ever cheap out on.
>boots
you should aim for boots over 200$ price range eventually, but if you are just getting started buy military surplus boots. But If you can avoid do not buy the recent desert tan army boots that run 20$. They have very thick soles and no ankle support , its a good way to give yourself a sprang ankle, they are also not very breathable or water proof. But I used them for a year so they are workable but do have a week or 2 brake in period.

Next is backpacks I see many on here choose a military surplus backpack, My experience with a US military molle 2 rucksack is that its usable at best but too heavy. Military sacrifices price and quality material for an indestructible pack that an idiot can't destroy. You are better off with a used frame backpack or internal backpack.

I have found that most milltary backpacks are around 65-120$ a used backpacking bag is around 20$ on shopgoodwill.com. I hear you say that you don't want to stand out in the woods , I would say their are plenty of waterproof rain flys for your bag that come in non-IRreflective camo for 45$ or a Chinese rain fly for 10$ on amazon, which are better than what ever camo you were thinking about buying any how. A good capacity is 65 liters, this is considered 3 day bag but if your smart you can fit rations for a full week in it. 55 liters is fine but the limit for fitting a sleeping bag and not limiting the gear you might want to take. Finally you need to have a waist support for your backpack as well as a frame , this should go without saying a duffel bag is a pain to hull around 5 miles.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?

com:
Good week for mushrooms ahead edition

>Community-based tools for IDing and Cataloguing
Mushroomobserver.org
The Bolete Filter: https://boletes.wpamushroomclub.org/
Inaturalist app (directly draws data from mushroomobserver but is itself a more generalized platform)
Google Scholar: Massive resource for papers and studies regarding current clinical and indigenous uses of medicinal fungi.

If you expect to get a remotely meaningful ID here, you need to be taking photos of the mushroom as you found it, on it's substrate, a clear shot of the top and side view of it, and a clear shot of the gills/pores/stipe/stem or otherwise the entire undercarriage of the mushroom. every detail of the encounter helps, where, when, what was the weather, etc.
If you want people who do this for a living to give their guess on ID's, take all of the above and make quality observations on Mushroomobserver.

This science needs as much redundant ID and loacation data as possible, any observation has value and is a meaningful contribution that takes a few more seconds than just taking a picture of the pretty thing you saw in the woods.

>>2505913
>>2505924
it's about building codes/minimum standards for dwellings more than anything.

i'm guessing mostly it's the fact that jurisdictions haven't really caught up to living offgrid. there really should be a variance for these types of dwellings. if someone wants to buy some land and build their house, install septic, etc etc on their timeline, that should be their right. no one is going to buy a fucking house on a plot of land and then realize "oh shit, it's not on the grid, fuck me, i didn't bother to see if there was electricity!"

like my county (lane, OR) has minimum dwelling sizes, septic/mains/well requirements, etc etc; which make it either outright impossible to buy land, and build a homestead from scratch, or make the permitting/siting process take so long that construction loans aren't feasible. For example: getting a conditional use permit for a dwelling on F2 land requires at least 18 months of paperwork and waiting around while some 25 y/o nitwit planner looks for reasons to deny your build, meanwhile construction loans typically have a 1 year conversion timeline. wife and i lucked out and found a property that already had the CUP on it, otherwise there was no way we could have swung the land purchase and rolled it into our construction loan.

it's such a fucky situation, one that a lot of the naive 20 somethings here completely fail to understand. then again if it were as simple as rolling an RV onto a plot of land and going for it, there wouldn't be any countryside left. Some states are probably more amenable to this kind of thing, but the overall trend seems to be to make moving out into rural areas more and more difficult -- environmentalism gone wild coupled with a subtle/backhanded mommy government hatred of proles and independence.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505997
No.

I'm assuming you mean no running water in the home, rather than just no water at all. My home has water. We have a well with an electric pump that handles the whole house and animals. Not the best showers in the world, but plenty of fresh water available as needed.

Electric isn't anything that a child needs to live a happy healthy life. The things provided by electricity can easily be handled by other means. The single best thing about having electric is refrigeration. Running the freezers so we can keep meat and other foodstuffs safely stored. If at all possible I generally try to avoid using power for unnecessary things.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505999
Sure.

We do seasonal pigs here. That is, we purchase feeder piglets from a local farm in the spring, and then they go to the butcher in the fall. We do this specifically to avoid overwintering pigs and dealing with full grown breeders. It's a lot less work on our part and we don't carry the burden of the breeding stock.

Because of this we have a 1.5 acre forest pasture rich in acorns for the pigs to live on. They shop up when they're young and easily handled. Already cut and weaned. We purchase pig feed from a local feed mill that has very reasonable prices and sources somewhat locally. Pigs handle the feed well and grow quickly. We only usually need to deworm them once during this process. As the weather is mild they generally don't need much housing. They destroy anything you give them anyways, so their run in always looks like shit.

We keep 2 for our family and sell the other 3+ which pays for all 5+ pigs every year. Essentially we 'eat for free'. We sell half shares of pork to friends and locals who buy into all the buzzwordy meat stuff. This is why they go to a butcher, because there's some regulations there on how meat sales and preparation are handled. I send my two along as well because our butcher does a much much better job than I do and the pork sales cover it 100%, so why not.

People want to eat meme breeds so Berkshires are very popular, but hybrids are generally more vigorous and less likely to fail to thrive. Berkshire crosses is what we generally handle here.

In a small operation, this is the most cost effective and easiest method by far. Every year we look into buying a male and two females to start our own breeding program. Planning on keeping 5+ piglets and selling the rest, but the cost of everything skyrockets and piglet sales alone won't cover all the costs, so the operation starts operating at a loss and my goal is always to break even on food.

>>2506594
Be visible. Be clean, with a good pack, so that people don't think you are a bum. Have a sign for where you are going. Smile, look at the drivers as they go past.

Plan your position on the road - you need to be somewhere that drivers can see you, have enough time to decide to stop, have a good space where they can stop and start up again. This will need to be a lot longer distance if you are on highway vs a country road.

1. Run the backing through your rod down to the reel
2. Hold spool on a pencil with feet/hands or recruit another person if you're a normie
3. Adjust appendages/partner pressure on the spool by more/less skin touching it
4. When you feel it's nice and tight, reel smoothly
5 (extra tips). Make sure to tie a good knot from backing to braid, and buy more braid than you think you'll need, either guestimate backing amounts with some quick maffs or buy/use a cheap and shitty reel to spool braid + backing on in reverse and the reel it onto the actual reel.

The restaurants in Northern PA are mostly unexceptional. Some exceptions:

The Summit restaurant on 219 near Ridgway has outstanding bar food (burgers, wings, ribs, all that).
Alfie's, a shack in Erie, have some of the better wings I've had outside of Buffalo with unique sauces.
Freeport Landing (North East) and Moe's (Coudersport) had decent food at honest prices, but no longer exist.
Primanti Bros is always good for their cheese fries, though their sandwiches are hot trash.
I have yet to have a decent pizza anywhere in Pennsylvania, or Ohio for that matter. I'm sure they exist somewhere. They're just harder to find.

sub: Why do people like kukris so much?
com: I bought myself a kukri a year or so ago, used it extensively as a camp duty tool. It really seems like a neat idea in theory but in practice it just doesn't work for me no matter how hard I try. It's too cumbersome to be a good replacement for a knife, it's too light to be a good replacement for a hatchet. It's also a pain in the ass to take care of due to the fact that it has a recurve shape. The only scenario where it's actually reasonable to use it is clearing slightly thick branches or really thick weeds where a regular machete doesn't have enough weight to cut through. I can't count how many times I found myself wishing I packed proper tools instead. Why are people so obsessed about these things? Have I fallen for a meme?

West Coast Trail on Vancouver Island is a good 5-6 day haul, unfettered beaches, old shipwreck rubbish, crashing waves with nothing but ocean between you and Japan, waterfalls and ladders, self-propelled cable gondolas over clear rivers, humpback whales and bald eagles, lush PNW forests...a little tent restaurant in the middle of the trail with $25 burgers, Washington State visible across the Juan de Fuca Strait going south..but as usual on the Island, there can be relentless rain and ankle-deep mud, with a full pack you may only clear 10 kilometers on an inclement day.

Definitely something to consider.

>That's still retarded. What are you treating that needs drench every few months?

Not same guy I just saw this thread but hes talking things for internal parasites, worms, Oxfendazole, Levamisole et cetera a lot of these kind of products also contain minerals such as selenium cobalt which may be deficient in the soil some places, ewes are not going to need drench so often they will have some natural resilience to worm burden but young lambs can be quite susceptible and get fucked up if you ignore it. Cost maybe 20-50 cents a dose here. Worms are going to slow their growth and if you are buying weaned store lambs from elsewhere you may have a timeframe you want to finish them in to take your profit, this also means in effect a weight gain target, not to mention worms affect on digestion is also going to leave them with dags for you to deal with. It's quite common here in NZ to round up lambs monthly and give them a drench to leave them with minimal worm burden but yeah it's also going to depend on the level of parasites present on the farm and the level of resilience bred into the stock how much good it is going to do, some breeders may run a program where they won't drench and simply cull those who can't handle themselves.. Another thing to watch is parasites which develop resistance to the chemicals in some cases and which can be moved from farm to farm inside the animals if they have not been drenched just a few days prior to movement or drench and quarantined on arrival .t finish about 2000 lambs a year when I want to (sheep are a pain in my ass and sometimes run less and more cattle instead)

The pic related you replied to is most likely a Japanese Spider Crab, another North Pacific species. The Pacific is the wild west of the worlds oceans and covers 1/3rd of the worlds total surface area. We have not even begun to understand or explore its full breadth in excess detail. An interesting feature of the subarctic/arctic and subantarctic/antarctic waters of the Pacific is that they are unusually rich in nutrients.

Another separate but random interesting fact, in the 70s a mild but good tasting orangish fish (Orange Roughy) was commercially fished off of Australia and New Zealand in the south Pacific, it was later determined that individual fish that people were eating had lived for up to 250 years and took a very long time to mature. last_replies.com:
when adding water, don't add it straight from your community water line/tap. 99% of the world adds chlorine (and more) to the water and this will kill the fish if added too soon in too large of volume

you will need to add the water gradually and wait (dilute it into the existing livable water the fish are in) to let it evaporate out, adding it into containers first then pouring it in is another option
you can add "water fix" stuff to correct for too much chlorine, etc in bodies of water, but that is not an optimal solution

keep some mosquito fish in the pond along with the koi. you wont need to feed the koi if you have even 1-2 small plants in the pond, to attract insects
They will eat minnows and plant debris
They will die if in the care of a old senile silver spoon deracinating boomer for more than a few days

sub: Legitimately dangerous east coast woods general.
com:
So a lot of people remember the storm on May24th weekend of this year that created some of the most historic timber damage dating back past the infamous "ice storm" of the 90s.

I've been working in residential and commercial tree removal and got to see first hand that amount of straight up damage to property from fallen trees, broken tops of Sw, Maple losing large limbs, length wise cracks on co-dominant trees straight onto the house roof, etc.

That being said, the thing that has struck me has been on crown land or in woodlots looking into the treeline now that all the leaves have fallen and seeing the the ridiculous number of danger trees. The other day we were on wooded private property removing some large but otherwise healthy poplar. The primary site hazard is dangerous trees x100. Multiple snags 45 degree angle or greater, a lot of the dead ash trees have now toppled onto healthy or unhealthy trees. Certainly want to be careful winter camping when setting up in the dark, a nice clearing might be underneath a few snags all leaning on each other.

It applies at any temperature and level of activity. In theory, you could always wear the perfect amount of clothes to not sweat and be fine with nonbreathable gear. That may be as low as slightly above freezing. You need to exert yourself quite a bit to not need *any* insulative clothing at that temperature.

Pretty much everyone I know uses a tree stand or just sits in one spot, which is fine if you just want to kill deer for food, but if the only way I can hunt is from a tree stand I'm not gonna hunt. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I've had one for about 25 years, still going strong. Pretty good for drizzle and light rain you get in the Northwest, but when it starts blowing sideways, the protection isn't quite there , even with your collar up. It has a fuzzy lining so it's definitely on the warmer side. The expanded peripheral vision over a hood is great for fighting claustrophobia and lets you hear what's going on. It doesn't pack very small with the extra bulk in the brim. It does pair well with a bug net as it keeps them off your face.
